commentText: When I was in highschool, it was nursing. commentText: Gonna be honest, the male nurses I have had were some of the best, most passionate, most understanding nurses I have ever met. And the ones that became ARNs and ARNPs were extremely good at listening to me and helping me form a solid plan and procedure. This isn't to say the female nurses are bad, but the men willing to deal with the stigma are the same that will work their tail off for the sake of being there for passion not paycheck.  It also helps with male nurses being around as it also gives some men a more solid and sympathetic connection. There are things culturally that male nurses and male patients can address that female nurses either aren't really exposed to or that the patient doesn't feel comfortable addressing with a female nurse.  I hate the stigma on both ends. Anyone going into a career should do it out of wanting to be there, not just because they need to optimize the paycheck and which government programs will reduce their long term debt.

videoTitle: WTF Happened To Florida?!
videoDescription: After moving to Florida, many people have found out the hard way and ended up suffering the costly pitfalls! Some new Florida ...
commentText: My wife and I moved to Florida in 2003. We left in 2019. Why? Many of the things Jerry mentions. We lived in the Tampa Bay area. When we got there, housing prices were reasonable. Insurance costs were manageable. Auto insurance was high but not too high. It  didn't start to get hot until late May, really hot after June 15. It would start cooling in mid October. The rest of the time the climate was ideal. But that changed. We started getting more 90 degree days as early as February. We were getting hot weather up until Thanksgiving. Look up the number of 90 degree days in a year in some parts of Florida. And like people say, its not the heat its the humidity. 90 degrees and 80% humidity during the day and 88 degrees with 95% humidity at night. Traffic congestion in any metro area in Florida is horrible. Even the I4 corridor between Tampa and the east coast can be stop and go for miles around the Disney properties. Hurricanes, tropical storms and lightening strikes are frequent. You can still see the stars and bars flown in lots of places in Florida.  What's good about Florida. Sports teams, major entertainers play in all the major cities, when the weather is nice it's great. Good parks everywhere, easy cycling, lots of amenities. Plenty of 'big city' ambiance. Good restaurants and everywhere is close to water for boating, fishing, etc. We moved to southern Virginia. No snow, more rural, less congestion. Lower cost of living probably because there is less to do. Some people don't mind the heat and Florida is ideal for them. For my wife and I, the heat and being indoors so much of the time to avoid the heat, finally got us to move.

videoTitle: WTF Happened To Florida?!
videoDescription: After moving to Florida, many people have found out the hard way and ended up suffering the costly pitfalls! Some new Florida ...
commentText: I have lived in Canberra, Australia for almost 35 years due to a fairly unusual set of circumstances. However, in another life far, far, away, I lived in Florida for approximately 30 years, 1960 to 1990. It truly was a great place to grow up apart from rarely having serious cold weather which I do like sometimes and do get where I live in Australia. The phrase that I would use to describe Florida today is 'complete lack of balance'. It is deficient in so many aspects. Environmentally, governance issues, traffic nightmares, overcrowding, I could go on and on but the narrator pretty much nailed many of the social ills of the state as they exist today. Just one small example that points out how the place has changed and as I come back fairly infrequently these days, I really notice changes. One stark example is the following: I lived in Orlando for 22 years before moving here, Jacksonville for 8 years before that. Hwy 50 (Colonial Drive) goes east-west right through the middle of the state from Brevard County all the way to the west coast, ending in Hernando County. In the late 1970's before 3 devastating freezes in the 1980's exacted a savage toll on Central Florida's citrus industry, you went from Orange County into Lake County entering just east of Clermont. Highway 50 was at that time in that area, a two lane road in the rural areas generally with light traffic. I can honestly remember seeing as you headed west, vast citrus groves for as far as the eye could see, literally. It was an amazing sight to see, now it is, counting both sides, an 8 to as much as a 12 lane road and the citrus groves in that region have totally disappeared, replaced by hundreds and hundreds of commercial buildings on both sides of the road. In fact, due to citrus greening, the state's production of what used to be the sweetest, most delicious citrus you ever ate, has plummeted to levels last seen in the mid 1930's. A once very proud industry is virtually on its knees today due to hurricanes, freezes, costs to grow crops, and diseases of myriad sorts. What has also happened there with invasive species, the draining of swamps, completely inappropriate building over much of the state and just the train wreck that the state has become is heartbreaking, especially for those of us who remember a place that was so much different and better than what those who live there today are likely experiencing. I am so blessed to now live in the city that in 2014 was voted the #1 city on the planet in which to live, the Capital of Australia. I will always have a fond place in my heart for Florida, as it once was. Good luck to all of you who reside in the state now. It can't be easy to do so.

commentText: Tangent: Florida is a really beautiful place.  My wife is a physician assistant who practices family medicine. We're in Texas and the cost of living in natural disasters on the coast are affecting us, too.   We've noticed that there is an increasing push to get family medicine and general practitioners into Texas and Florida as the country sees more and more family doctors retire and family health care deserts expand.   As medical schools, physician assistant master's degree programs, and nurse practitioner programs become increasingly ethnically diverse and more female, we're noticing that fewer of those students are interested in being in red states.  If they have a choice, people will avoid going to places where they are not welcome or safe.  We're an LGBT/interracial family, and we feel much less safe and much less welcome in Texas, where we live, and have no plans to venture into Florida for the same reasons.  We've had a few headhunters try to entice my wife into interviews with corporate healthcare chains in Florida, and we won't consider it at all.  I hope Floridians can make the necessary changes to their state to make it more affordable and attractive again.

commentText: My go to: ask where they want you to be 1 week, 1 month, and before the end of the probationary period in terms of skill and independence. It 1. shows long term commitment and 2. makes them SEE YOU in that role. You've told them about your work history and made some basic rapport, now make them picture you in the role.   (I'm autistic and worked in HR. Most interviewers are zoned out at best, say something interesting or weirdly specific to make you stand out. I bring up projects that weren't company focused, but internally focused, making me seem more stable and long term. üëçüèΩ but also it is a tough job market even for the most qualified people... I know people with phds working part time right now)

commentText: Consider the people receiving your resume. A sister in OR reported a shelving position opening up at her library where she was a librarian. They had over 400 applicants. She and a couple other librarians had little time to sort each one out. They decided the cover letter should be 1/2 a page (as we have generally all been told). So they began by throwing out any application where the cover letter was over 1/2 a page. Then they looked to see which cover letters had typos and/or misspellings. They tossed out those.  So etc, etc. It sounds terribly unfair, and it was in some instances. But imagine if 400 or 1400 applications arrived on your desk. You're supposed to evaluate them. How will you start? Where will you start?

videoTitle: WTF Is Happening To The Job Market
videoDescription: Something is seriously wrong with the job market and it's about to get worse. The modern job search has become a frustrating and ...
commentText: The housing collapse was the first crack. Banks gambled, collapsed, and got taxpayer bailouts. Executives handed themselves bonuses with public money while the public paid the price. Occupy Wall Street tried to push back, but nothing truly changed. The same players stayed in power. The rules stayed rigged.  Now we are living through the next phase. Mass layoffs, ghost jobs, AI filters, and stagnant wages are everywhere. Profits soar, shareholders celebrate, and executives cash out while telling workers to be grateful for scraps.  Meritocracy is gone. Optics replaced it. Corporate success is no longer built on value or skill, but on who can perform the best image while cutting the people they parade for PR. Behind the curtain, the human element is gone, and the fa√ßade grows thicker.  AI is not the enemy. The real danger is AI CEOs and executives who treat technology as their personal crown. They are not building; they are competing to out-narcissist each other, blinded by ego and greed. Investors fuel this arms race because it spikes their portfolios, no matter the long-term damage. Behind closed doors, the C-suite and shareholders pat themselves on the back while carving out what remains of the middle class.  This is not about politics. It is about power. The ultra-wealthy control the levers and have no interest in building a system that works for anyone else. This is the second reckoning. The first was the manufacturing carve-out that gutted entire communities. This one is a technological carve-out, and its effects are already eroding the workforce from within.  If you feel invisible, you are not imagining it. This market is not broken; it is built to extract and discard. Until people stop accepting optics for progress and demand substance, the machine will keep grinding through generation after generation.  The ultra-wealthy will not save us. They are too busy competing to see who can burn it down the fastest.

commentText: I closed my laptop two minutes into an interview. Posted as remote, anywhere in my province. The interviewer asked how my day was going so far, I said something about the weather in my city that day. They froze, then said something about needing to be onsite (which was 4hrs away) once a week. I reminded her the posting only indicated remote work and she apologized for it being incorrect. I mentioned that I had another application pending for the same org, and wondered if she knew anything about the status of it. When I told her the position title, she told me it was a duplicate posting just worded slightly different. I told her there was a $35k difference between the two job listings. She froze again and I left the call shaking my head. That was one of only five interviews I got out of 70+ applications in a year.

commentText: I drove 45 minutes and showed up to a job interview and told the people at the front desk that I was here for an interview.  They looked confused and asked me for the name of the person I was supposed to be interviewing.  I gave them the name.  A little bit later, that person came out and we went into a private room to start talking.  They told me that the job was "recently filled" and there wasn't anything currently open anymore, but that they liked my resume enough that they wanted to talk to me in-person for "potential future opportunities".  At this point, I was seething so hard, I wanted to yell at them for wasting my time or say something snarky to this hiring manager.  But I practiced self control and played along and did my best as if the job was open, all the while rage was boiling in my stomach;  I didn't want to burn any bridges in-case this company is my last resort down the line and they do have something open in the far future.    But what a waste of my time, my whole day was wasted on this that could have been spent searching/applying for more jobs or preparing for a real interview.

commentText: I‚Äôm from a small community in New England. I used to think that one day I‚Äôd want to get a fancy corporate job in a city like New York or Boston. But now the entire process of getting one of those jobs is sounding less and less appealing, let alone realistic. I work at a public library in my hometown and never had to worry about competing with hundreds of other candidates, getting ghosted by the company, or getting interviewed by AI. The person I emailed my resume to is the same person who interviewed me and who is now my boss. I used to think we were at a disadvantage living in a smaller place, with fewer opportunities, but now I see we are actually so lucky to have a job market with real people and real jobs.

commentText: Hearing to tailor the resume for each job posting, on top of already tailoring the cover letter for each job post, sounds fine in a small scale. But is unbelievably exhausting in reality. A lot of us applying to hundreds of jobs are doing that. It feels like it's just a pure numbers game rather than anything else. No matter how perfect a resume, cover letter, skills/abilities you have, experience history, etc., none of that seems to matter in the grand scheme of things. It's either you know someone, are able to know someone (and they're also willing to give you the time of day, which many aren't), or you have the willpower and patience to send out an infinite number of applications just for the hope of hearing back from a small few. Sorry if this sounds defeatist, I do appreciate the discussion and the advice, but this just eats away at you to where you just don't feel human anymore.

And as adults we have no idea how to prepare the next generations for what the future of work will look like. commentText: What is wrong with the job market? We‚Äôre in a government policy induced economic crash. The federal government has purposefully crashed the economy to forestall entitlement reforms, tax reform, immigration reform, and industrial policy reform. Any reforms would risk uprooting entrenched financial positions so they‚Äôre crashing the economy instead. AI should be a boon for productivity but that can only happen during economic growth periods. So that‚Äôs why the AI is fundamentally useless. AI allows people to do more work to less knowledge, but when the government increases inflation by printing money while simultaneously making it more and more expensive to hire and import, we get an economic crash instead of an uptick in quality of life. By the end of 2028 there will be a full blown economic depression similar to 2008, or perhaps even worse.

commentText: it's the K shaped economy that's the root of all this. we let wealth inequality get so out of control that if the bottom 60% stopped all their consumer spending in its entirety, you'd only see a 20% reduction in purchases across the economy (a mild recession, but not catastrophic). at the same time, even a few % decrease in spending by the top 20% and the entire economy collapses. this has forced businesses and governments to create policy around that upper sector, and largely ignore the bottom 60% because, in economic terms, theyre irrelevant. theyre too poor and have too little purchasing power to cater to.   this is what happened in the 1880s-1920s, and it's happening again. the difference is today we can just replace the productive capacity of the bottom with automation. people really dont understand how bad this will get. even in the 1930s, despite massive government intervention, the economy never recovered. it took a world war to pull the US out of the slump, because a world war forced a redistribution of wealth (high taxes to pay for the war effort, followed by financial repression on those who own assets and a need for mass mobilization of the population which led to political concessions to guarantee cooperation) which reset the game. we're headed towards a feudalism with robots, or revolution. maybe both.

videoTitle: Why is the Job Market on the Brink of Collapse?
videoDescription: jobmarket #tech #techlayoffs The U.S.A job market is facing major strain as layoffs rise and automation accelerates. Despite ...
commentText: When a company wants 3-5 years of experience for an entry level job: 1. They aren't actually hiring. They're posting jobs pad the "jobs created" numbers. They're going to use it as leverage to say "they can't find qualified people" and pressure the government to allow them to hire more non-citizens on visa for cheaper (ex: the H1B visa program). OR, they're going to use it as an excuse for diving more into automation to justify replacing those jobs with AI and make someone at the company look good by "solving a problem" with AI.  2. They don't want people fresh out of school. You've all probably seen the BS reasons given for this. Look it up if you haven't, but there are companies that don't want to hire Gen Z workers fresh out of school right now. They often won't come out and say it because they don't want to spend money handling the backlash, but it's essentially what they're doing. As a reminder, age discrimination is LEGAL for anybody under 40. It's not until you hit age 40 and above that you now have a legal right against age discrimination in the US.  3. They're keeping wages down. Someone with 3-5 years of work experience is worth more than an entry level job salary, but if they can't get a higher position somewhere, they'll have to take the lower paying "entry level" position even if the "other duties as assigned" aspect of the job is actually something that would normally be done at a higher position. The reason why this is significant is because wages DO get tracked. Companies look at that data and think about ways they can squeeze more work out of every individual and if they can spread some work normally done by someone in a higher position among entry level workers to "give them experience" while keeping the amount they pay to get that work done lower, they consider it as "win/win". The bright eyed, eager entry level worker gets more exposure and experience and the company gets to pay less to get the work done. Now they can use AI to take more of the work load as well.  This isn't anything new. The same thing happened in the fallout of the dotcom bubble bust in the early 2000s. Younger GenX and older Millenials went through the same thing. Even before AI, people were writing software for automation. It IS unfair. It ruined those people's lives and prevented them from having a good start after school. Millions of people were screwed just by the timing of them entering the workforce. There was NO help for them. There will be NO help for GenZ entering the workforce today. In addition to that millions of other older workers had their careers destroyed as well. It was a dark time and then just as things showed signs of getting better, the Great Recession happened in the late 2000s.  Today, we're also heading to a major recession. It's a VERY bad sign when AI spending from few companies is literally propping up the US economy right now. The writing is on the wall. This situation may improve somewhat for a few people who finally break into the workforce, but a recession is coming to knock them and everyone else down.  I REALLY wish there was a better outlook coming, but there isn't. All any of us can do (young and older workers alike) is keep on trying. Giving up won't pay the bills or put food on the table. After we get through the coming dark times, things will eventually get better for everyone, but we have to keep trying and sometimes fight to get there.

commentText: I find this whole situation so strange. We‚Äôre seeing record stock market highs, billions flying around in investments, companies going public, and all this talk about growth. Yet at the same time more than a million people who used to be taxpayers are being pushed out of the workforce and handed back to the government to support. How does that even make sense?  If the economy is doing so well, why hasn‚Äôt a single meaningful law been passed to protect workers and keep people employed? How do we accept millions of people shifting from contributors to tax absorbers, while pretending everything is fine?  The numbers don‚Äôt add up. Something in this system is fundamentally broken.

commentText: This is not the deeper underlying root of the chaos unraveling in the job market though. Yes, companies are reporting record profits while job growth is stagnant ‚Äî but the real issue goes deeper. With real-time analytics and constant quarterly-report pressure, executives are fixated on hitting KPIs every 90 days instead of building anything long-term.  So the ‚Äústrategy‚Äù becomes layoffs, cost-cutting, and efficiency pushes ‚Äî because that‚Äôs the only reliable way to churn higher profits. They‚Äôre not generating those profits through innovation or sustained growth; they‚Äôre squeezing the organization to make the numbers look good.  And now that AI can replace a lot of lower-level work, I don‚Äôt know if this cycle ever reverses. We‚Äôve identified the problem, but I‚Äôm not convinced the old job market ever comes back.

commentText: The woman who accidentally bought $9,000 worth of stuff on Amazon‚Ä¶  Amazon keeps your credit and address data and you can create more than one account, with different cards.  Or switch your account‚Äôs default to another card.   But when you buy on Amazon, it doesn‚Äôt ask you for ANYTHING.    It doesn‚Äôt ask for your card, or your address.   It just Says ‚ÄúPurchase Completed‚Äù as it uses the last card you used, and the address you sent it to.   So it‚Äôs entirely possible she was tasked with ordering some company stuff online and input the company card, but then did not realize that her home computer would default to that card whenever she went on Amazon.

commentText: Honestly almost 2 1/2 years ago I quit my security job. I have no regret whatsoever but I couldn‚Äôt find a job for almost 3 months. I was begging God every single day. I had a phone number from a stranger, she gave me her program managers personal phone number. We scheduled an interview and same day I got hired. 2 years later I‚Äôm still grateful to have this job. Moral of the story don‚Äôt quit until you have another job!

commentText: Worked at small tech company of about 30 people.  One day they 'temporarily' laid off everyone but the managers and 5 workers. All 5 including myself were the the most senior workers in the company, so we all thought it was just a nice acknowledgement by the company.  About a year later they announced the company was closing, and we learned from one manager that the only reason us 5 were kept on for a year were due to the employment contracts we signed  years ago (back when the future was very bright and people were hired at higher than market salaries).     Got a nice severance, and now retired.

videoTitle: I GOT FIRED! Job Market TANKS & People Are Getting Laid Off
videoDescription: 2nd Channel @ZacV2 Chapters 0:00 Subscribe! Chapters 0:00 Subscribe! 0:36 Job Report 2:15 Fired By Text 3:02 Comment ...
commentText: Never be loyal. The contract between you and your job is...Show up on time to work, do your job, get your money, go home. Years of service does not make you loyal. The higher pay, the accumulation of vacation time, and the hours of sick time and PTO earned makes you a liability. Knowledge, experience, and expertise gained over the years be damned.

commentText: As a former Director Of Operations at a healthcare company, headcount is everything.  It‚Äôs not like it used to be where a manager is given a budget and the company sticks to that.  Nowadays, if financial goals are not being met, the budget gets adjusted and the first thing to go is labor. Build yourself a financial war chest and remain debt free. Be prepared because it likely will happen to almost everyone!

commentText: In the course of one week, both my parents and myself were laid off.  My mother was with her company for 27 years, her job was sent to India. My Dad was the top salesman and was there for 7 years. I was with my previous company for 6 years, we went from 16 clients to over 250 clients while I was with that company.  Thankfully I found work, but I have 12 years of experience in computer and network engineering. Mom is struggling to find work and she's a highly skilled and 27 year experienced project manager. Dad found another job doing the same thing with another company, thankfully.

commentText: Honestly, if you have a clean record and go into it for the right reasons (not just to flex or bully), I‚Äôve enjoyed my job in law enforcement more than any other I‚Äôve ever had. You have to keep in mind, though, if you‚Äôre actively on the streets with a local agency, it can be extremely taxing on your mental health constantly dealing with people when they‚Äôre not at their best and the graveyard hours are a challenge. However, the pay is great, you‚Äôre helping the community be safer, and you‚Äôre not cooped up in an office.   I spent a lot of my life before in a corporate role and it‚Äôs definitely rough. You are only a commodity, a number on a spreadsheet, whose sole purpose is to increase the return for shareholders. I don‚Äôt know why it is they think they can even do that when no one has any money to buy their product.

commentText: Early last year, I finally snapped and could no longer deal with my current job- hated hated HATED the work itself, everything else was fine. But I was losing my mind so I quit. I had some savings so I thought it'll be fine- started applying to jobs. I put in near 300 applications in like 2 months and I only got 1 callback. I secured that job but it was SO bad, so low-paying and I hated it more than my previous job. Drained my savings, was miserable. I was looking to apply to school so I reached out to my old managers asking if they'd be willing to write a letter of recommendation for me, and I mentioned that I missed working for them so if they wanted me back, I'd love that. I thought they hated me- turns out they didn't hate me!! They took me back and it's been soooo much better. I still hate the job itself but I am much more grateful than before.  I'm echoing everyone else: DO NOT QUIT YOUR JOB. Hold onto it with a death grip. Things are only getting rockier from here on out! And if you left an old job, maybe reach out and ask. You never know if they want you back too!

commentText: I graduated HS in 2006 and almost went to ITT Tech until they told me it would cost 50k per semester for 4 years. I knew there was no way I could pay that much money back with interest (and they turned out to be a scam school anyway) so I started working in a factory. I've worked in several factories, warehouses, and a few retail stores and at every job I was working side by side with college graduates who couldn't find jobs, making the same money as me but they have student loans to pay and I don't. I've been working in an organic co-op grocery store for the past year and a half making only a dollar less per hour than I was making in a warehouse, but I get tons of free food which makes up for that dollar an hour loss. Most of my coworkers are college graduates but here we are working together.

commentText: 22:30 Job scams are so sickening yet common. When I was searching for a job last year, I was emailed a job opportunity. The email sources weren't gibberish and mimicked the real life emails of the actual company's workers.  I was invited into a Teams interview where I typed my answers to an "interviewer" via messages, not through a voice all. Sketchy enough, yet the scam completely impersonated not one, but two actual workers of the company on LinkedIn and even stole a version of the actual company's job offer to email to me.  I was able to cancel my private info at my bank when I thought it was exposed. I was able to piece together the scam by calling in twice where on each occasion where I spoke to a "workers," I noticed their accents and voices sounded identical.  It was absolutely fucked.

commentText: That's really hits home hard for me.   A round of end of last year I was working at a cook position at Panda Express. The manager was very happy with me and he was training me to become a chef/assistant manager. Harbor after I finally got a new position at a hospital for beginner it position, I gave my 2 weeks and accepted the new position.   Put on the first day of my new job I was told that the position was terminated.  About a month later I was picked up to become a testing validation engineer for car company. I actually really enjoyed the job and the pay was pretty decent. What about 6 months and I got into a very bad car accident and the testing vehicle was totaled. Without a testing vehicle and the recording equipment I was basically no longer eligible for work and the project was terminated.   But through some connections from the previous job, I was able to get a controls engineer job at a different bigger company in a different city. Everything was going well my co-workers really liked and they were teaching me a lot about the factory and how to work the machines, what about 1 months and a half into my job they laid off the entire department.   Right now I have a few interviews set up but I'm still struggling to find a job and a place to stay.

commentText: I was downsized from three jobs in my working life. My husband from two. For a while we were both downsized from our respective companies. I took middle of the road paying jobs, working in offices and libraries, he worked in factory shipping departments.             We have one car between us so I had to get jobs where I could take the bus to work, we have no cable TV, no dishwasher, no air conditioning, no smart phones, just basic flip phones and a landline, buy reasonable quality groceries, and seldom eat out, go camping locally for vacations, buy affordable gifts for holidays, contribute to charity,  have some nice second hand furniture and wear nice clothing from local thrift stores. No credit card dept. We saved our money. It can be done.

videoTitle: I GOT FIRED! Job Market TANKS & People Are Getting Laid Off

commentText: I am a recent grad (cybersecurity) and over the course of 2 months, I applied for over 300 jobs, i received abt 150 rejection emails and only two call backs (and two interviews). Of those two. I got one job offer for $2 an hr less than what I initially agreed to in the interview. I had to take it because I had no other options and 6k in CC debt from trying to survive 2 months with no income. (plus 50k in student loans I will be expected to pay back in Nov 2026)

videoTitle: I GOT FIRED! Job Market TANKS & People Are Getting Laid Off

commentText: I worked as a customer service rep back in 2019-2021. It was a start-up located in Vancouver, Canada). When COVID hit, we were told our response times and service had improved tremendously since we started working remotely. But once they took on new investors/partners I noticed it was odd to shift some of our responsibilities to another "global company" that was in India. Fast forward to February 2021, we all get a meeting invite, and lo-and-behold, they had informed us that they were shutting our department down and outsourcing their Customer Service and have us 2 months notice, so no severance. It was so awkward though: everyone's cameras were on and you could tell that the one's that were upset shut off their cameras. Someone also entered late after they announced it, and interrupted and asked if they could repeat what was said and it was so awkward

commentText: It‚Äôs amazing that for someone that knows everything there is to know about everything, has no clue as to why the job numbers are revised every month. The monthly US jobs report, officially the Employment Situation Summary, is released on the first Friday of every month at 8:30 a.m. Eastern Time by the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS). Monthly job numbers are revised because the initial figures are preliminary estimates that become more accurate as the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) receives more responses from the monthly employer surveys. The BLS also incorporates more comprehensive state unemployment insurance records in a larger "benchmark revision" annually to provide a definitive picture of the labor market. These revisions, which are standard practice to ensure data accuracy, improve the timeliness of the preliminary numbers while still accounting for incomplete data collection.  Trump or any of his supporters that question why the revisions are made can google learn.

commentText: I live in St Petersburg Florida, which has seen unprecedented migration from all over the country. It went from being a sleepy little town to a packed metropolis. Despite that, at the same time every business is closing, cutting hours or laying people off. A Wendy's just closed, a Checkers just closed. Village Inn cut hours, IHOP cut hours. The local ice cream shop that's been around since the 60s closed, the local burger place that's been open since the 60s closed. Home Shopping Network closed. For the first time since the 1970s we don't have a 24-hour or even late night grocery store. I know people with multiple college degrees who have been looking for a job for the past 6 months with no luck. There are homeless people everywhere. When I do ride sharing I take people with full-time jobs home to efficiency apartments, trailer parks and motel rooms.  The average studio apartment is over $2,000. I'm pretty sure that there's a crash coming any moment now.

commentText: It's good to have multiple trade skills like plumbing, electrician, HVAC, roofer, framer, painter, landscaping, road paver, machanic, nursing, etc. That way you can pivot to the jobs that are in demand when your job goes away. My mistake was I didn't invest in myself and didn't learn multiple skills until I was laid off this year. Right now I am learning to be an electrician and it's going to take another 8 months to finish. I would recommend to anyone that is employed at a single job, go and get certified in other fields while you have the opportunity. It will be less stressful than when you have to work minimum wage job, do a side hustle, and learn a new skill.

commentText: The economy is suffering due to poor fundamentals.  These include the overall phenomenon called "structural unemployment."  Some economists have predicted this for decades because of its Malthusian essence.  Too many people, not enough jobs.  It will never return to what was.  It's not part of normal economic cycles that the experts are so fond of citing. It's exacerbated by AI and robotics.  Unless the government was proactive in planning to make society more socialistic, and improving conditions for citizens, then it's a down hill slide towards a plutocracy. Unfortunately that's the widening chasm between the rich and the poor, leaving the mid-class in tatters trying to maintain their standard of living in a country where the average person is involved in a non-consensual relationship with an economy hell bent on fleecing the shit out of people.  The automobile is the biggest fraud ever perpetrated on a populace. Just add up all the costs inherent in the operation of your car and hang up and drive.  The fender bender industry wants you on your phone, with headlights unique to each model and absurd prices for injection molded parts with insane margins. Back to the acyclic economic milieu in which we exist.  The end of the petroleum age means that we are seeing prices rise based on a truer calculation of embedded costs.   The slow death of urban core retail means that commercial real estate is getting shitty, and that sector has anchored funds and such for years.   Bankers are slow to adjust. Every company is squeezing everything for revenue, meaning the firings and the terrible job market are the tip of the iceberg. The guy who got voted in isn't doing anything to help you folks that believed the rhetoric.  He just wants to aggrandize himself and his cronies by reviving the polluting of our country while bad mouthing renewable energy because of its effect on the "landscape."   Since when has he given a shit about the natural world? Has he visited an open pit mine recently.  He has doubled his net worth over the last 6-18 months, while most US citizens are suffering.   Make no mistake: He doesn't give a shit about any of us, unless you're part of the war machine dominated by the Big 5 and go to Davos or Tetons.   Over Easter he dismissed us all and said "just enjoy your life" in a display of such callous indifference the average person's plight as to be obscene. He has begun to take away the basic right to free speech and his attacks on people smarter than he is who criticize what is happening is truly frightening.  We should all be very concerned and petition our generally greedy representatives who are often focused on their own inside information making their assisted stock market picks way easier. Stop attacking people who you might call liberal and understand that it will require all of us to find accord and quorum to achieve any progress.   Infighting and factionalism will be our downfall.

commentText: For my outdoor projects here in Florida, I always use Stainless Steel decking screws  because the regular screws rust out in just a few years. One year ago, a 1 lb box of SS screws cost $12. Six months ago, the same scews cost $17 /box. Today, I was shocked to see the same box of screws are now $23 /box. That's an increase of about 95% in a year. Where are they getting this 3% inflation rate they keep promoting?  Almost everything I buy now is double the price it used to be.

commentText: And people wondering why college graduates can't make rent:  4-year Bachelor's graduates: Make $1100 a month National rent average: $1900 a month Food cost: $400 per month per person Utilities: Roughly $800-1200 per month, not including internet service Phone bill: $100 per month, minimum Car payment: $200 per month lease Fuel: @$3.00 per gallon, 15-gallon gas tank, 300 miles per tank: $180 per month, more if you get stuck in city "stop-and-go" traffic  Add it all up, and the following becomes true.  In 1980, you could buy a house ($47,000) on a minimum wage ($3.10 per hour). Rent was an average of $243 per month. Groceries was $40 a week/$160 per month.  In 2025, the cost to buy a house is 9.8 times what it was in 1980, at a national average of $417,000. Yet minimum wage is only $7.25 an hour, up from $3.10 per hour. It used to be $80,000 per year was considered middle class; now middle class is $185,000.  Point is, the old thinking is for an old age. The Industral Age has given way to the Information Age, and no longer do the old ways work, simply because the old ways has put way too many people in a hole they will never get out of.  Minimum yearly salary is not $35,000 anymore, for even entry-level. My guess is that minimum yearly salary should be around $50,000 per year.  And companies need to stop passing the buck on costs to consumers, who are already paying way too much as it is.

videoTitle: Americans Are FURIOUS At The INSANE Job Market
videoDescription: TikTok: https://www.tiktok.com/@jayyreed?_t=ZP-8xpYGIP7xPD&_r=1 Equipment I use in my videos: Swinging pendulum ...
commentText: We have no idea what this job is, or how many hours a week.  Assuming 40 hours, doing the math it comes to $16.75 per hour (assuming US).  That is apparently starting pay.  When I started working at 18 I made $3.85 an hour (in 1972; minimum wage was $1.60.).  I had multiple roommates; I paid $50 per month for a bed in an old farmhouse with no heat.  (In LA, so not so bad, but still...)  After five years my pay had more than doubled.  After seven years I had been promoted to a skilled craft job.  Five more years and I was promoted to "Engineering Assistant."  Four more years and they made me a Supervisor within my work group.  A decade more and the moved me into Engineering, making me a Senior Engineer a year later, and eventually a Lead Network Engineer.  The point being, does this job have a future, or is it a dead end?  That makes a huge difference in whether to accept the job or not.  (Besides the basic, "How much do I need some kind of job right now?)  These are the sorts of real-world considerations these superficial skits ignore.

commentText: Long, non-stop interviews are a sign of clueless managers. The longer you participate, the more you'll reek of desperation. A technical interview, at most, should be 1 - 2 hours with 3 people. If they can't size you up after that they never will.

commentText: I retired from the IT industry after getting training through the military, two CISCO cert schools, some cybersecurity. I applied to every IT job in the state and only got a couple interviews with no jobs. I learned that I should just create my own company. The stability of employment, even if you're broke, is way better than constantly trying to shift focus to appease meaningless entry level jobs. After doing my own thing, I am now creating c++ apps, have hired some work out, and have attracted new job offers (sorry but I'm going for gold now). Pursue your craft and jobs will become a side hustle to earn some cash.

Companies are exaggerating "AI Productivity" so they can explain to shareholders that they're laying people off for that reason, not due to having a bad quarter. Even among Senior Devs, the only ones I know landing jobs right now are finding them through personal networks.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I've come to the conclusion that I no longer want to chase after a language or framework. This changes all the time. I've also decided that I will no longer subject myself to being treated like a commodity at a cattle auction. In the end, all of this is designed to make you accept doing more for less. I think at some point we give in and accept unrealistic things because the "market demands it," or the influencer you follow or the group of followers in the bubble you're in dictates that this is the culture, technology, or method to be adopted. Yes, I went through a financial setback and had to accept working in other segments. But that didn't kill my desire to work with software. Today, I think the path is to work as an entrepreneur and consultant for small businesses, creating solutions for the region you live in or where you can work without creating a burden on your life. Another mistake I see is the industrialization of the IT workforce. We didn't start that way; we started in a garage or on a small project; we're not cattle.

videoTitle: The Brutal Reality of the Tech Job Market
videoDescription: The tech job market right now is brutal. Layoffs, endless applications, and constant rejections. It feels impossible to land an offer.
commentText: I worked in tech for 45 years in several roles. When I started, ‚ÄúBeing in computers.‚Äù, was like saying you were a Wizard in a tower. Your job was mysterious and magical and few others were in the industry competing for these enchanted positions. I retired a few years ago.  Nowadays, computer techs are a commodity and the perception is of an office worker. You are disposable and can be replaced in days from thousands of other candidates in your field. You‚Äôre no more important than a file clerk.  I worked through the tech industry‚Äôs best years and retired (age 60) at the tail end of that time.  Best of luck but it‚Äôs going to be a crap shoot and the jobs are pretty harsh.

commentText: I'm sorry the market is so brutal.  I would suggest, in the meantime, code your own apps for sale in the app store.  Doing this will achieve a few powerful things: (1) keep your skills fresh, (2) create something to show off, (3) potentially make some good money on the sale of your apps, and (4) keep your mind sharp, fresh.  You can also use this time to achieve certifications.  At the end of the day, give major consideration in the idea of working for yourself, building your own solutions.

commentText: The tech market isn't cooked, SWE jobs are cooked.  Lots of people don't realize there's so many other technical jobs out there to apply for. Look into Solution Engineer/Solutions Consultant roles, or Implementation Consultant, or Integration Specialist.  I went the implementation Consultant route, my current role only had 100 applicants in 2 weeks, meanwhile SWE jobs get 1000 applicants in 2 days.  I know it's easy to feel doomed but there are sooo many paths out there guys. I wouldn't even be surprised if I find myself as a SWE one day.

videoTitle: Why the Job Market is Worse Than Everyone Thinks
commentText: I think it's largely fueled by the same mess that companies have been trying to push for the past 20 years, but now it's failing them: budget cuts  They don't want to pay for training, so they only hire experienced people  They don't want to pay for experienced people, so they overwork their employees  They don't want to pay overtime, so they try under scheduling to force employees to work part time at multiple places, thus not getting benefits from any of them   They don't want to pay wages at all, so they _try_ to use AI instead   The global market is fully saturated, and we are running out of corners to cut on this circle. It's only a matter of time before The Big One hits...

videoTitle: Why the Job Market is Worse Than Everyone Thinks
commentText: Individuals not included in official unemployment statistics are typically those who are jobless but are not actively looking for work and after 20 weeks of unemployment people are dropped from the stats. The U.S. Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) considers a person "unemployed" only if they are jobless, available for work, and have actively looked for work in the last four weeks.  This doesn‚Äôt include, the homeless, disabled for any reason or those that quit without seeking unemployment.  The stats are skewed to the positive no matter how you look at it. It‚Äôs grim but the saddest part is it a vast amount of people are invisible in our culture.

commentText: If you do find a profitable thing, it is great for awhile, until other people crowd into it. I've seen that time after time. Amazon and Ebay selling were great at first, until people crowded into the market and became cutthroat in the secondhand market and both platforms started trimming profits and shipping compensation for sellers until you were taking a loss on everything you shipped, and they were taking much bigger cuts for your sales as well as charging for your listings. Customers also started stealing the product by claiming it wasn't delivered. Sellers were complaining customers would order something, switch out a part like a battery or an engine, put the dead battery or broken part in the shipped item and claim it was broken to get a refund.  Someone did it to me too on a four-hundred-dollar product. I decided I couldn't afford to ship things like that anymore because the losses were eating up the earnings. And there really was no practical way to sue customers who were ripping you off.

commentText: Declining rents mean one thing for the U.S. Housing Market: deflation.  When you see rents dropping at the same time homebuyer demand is at 30-year lows, it signals a deep and persistent demand problem. That weakness is now showing up across the country ‚Äî rents are falling, price cuts are rising, and more markets are entering outright decline.  For renters and first-time buyers, this is great news. It means 2026 is shaping up to be the most affordable year in housing since before the pandemic.  The downside? This is a brutal environment for investors and landlords. Rents are falling across the once-booming Sun Belt, compressing yields at the same time taxes and insurance keep climbing. Investors are selling more, buying less, and re-evaluating their portfolios.  But there are still opportunities. In the video, I broke down my top 3 most affordable markets heading into 2026 ‚Äî places where you can still buy a home or rental for $1,000/month or less on your mortgage payment (including taxes).  To find more markets where the numbers still work, go to www.reventure.app and upgrade to the premium package. Premium gives you full access to Cap Rates, Rental Rates, and Home Value-to-Rent data, all mapped down to the ZIP Code. commentText: You should add or recognize that many of these 'layoff' cases are a direct result of major companies 'over staffing' when so much FREE money was released by the government with no logical Quid-Pro-Quo or 'something for something'. Folks used their new money to BUY things that had to be sold and serviced by vendors - large and small.  Then, one day, there was no more freebies to artificially feed our economy. And, as in farm life, the chickens must go to roost and let the quiet night be.  Yes, I am just a two bit economic philosopher who's lived a long life - sometimes, maybe too dang long, as I played the full range of boss, employee and business owner in a number of different enterprises. Thanks for sharing.

commentText: I keep telling anyone who will listen: the architectural billings index, which tracks all architectural billing in the country (i.e. the construction industry) has been contracting since January. Construction is about 5% of gdp. You tell me if contracting construction activity is tantamount to a recession. To my mind, we have been in a recession since the architectural billing started contracting which is always a herald of recession in the rest of the economy a few months later. Construction is the most volatile and fluid part of the economy. It‚Äôs also the most sensitive to instability. A sharp contraction in construction absolutely sends shockwaves throughout everything else. The recession we are feeling is the consequence of halted and deferred construction projects. This is directly attributable to tariffs, which adversely impacted escalation costs and caused funding to be canceled.

commentText: Excellent analysis. We are on the verge of a liquidity crisis: tariffs are taxes on importers/consumers and they are running at an average of 20%, whereas in 2024 they were 2-3%, making 2025 a large take-a-away by government from corporations and citizens. The Fed doesn't control the bond market, only the Fed Funds rate (overnight bank lending rate). The trade deficit leads to a capital account surplus because exporters buy US stocks and bonds, making it cheaper for US consumers/corporations to finance at much lower rates.

commentText: I feel like this advise is extremely dangerous. The issue with supply and demand is, you can't just tell the population to do more work and prepare for negative circumstances because if everyone does this, the new average jumps up. More effort. Higher average. Higher average. More effort. Eventually, everyone will need to become demi-God's to work at Mcdonalds, and all you've done is worsen the situation. Well... The country just collapses at that point.The only change that works is on a systematic level. No individual's internal improvements to approaching a broken system are ever going to fix the system itself.   To the reader: You are good enough! Trust me, you're putting in way too much effort for your labour. It's not your fault. You're not inadequate. You should not feel like you have to get three degrees, have two backup plans, expect to work for two months before a layoff, earn 60k to afford a one bedroom apartment, be a master at every knew innovation that comes out, have 8 years of experience for a junior role, spend every day of your life sending 5 job applications. IT'S. NOT. YOU. The job market is the problem. Work on your hobbies and your art, and say no to corporate hell.

commentText: I heard that 25% of people with an MBA from Harvard (one of the best schools in the world!) can't get a job. People with a bachelor's degree flipping burgers at McDonald's in the States (overqualified at an entry level job!). People with a degree in Engineering or a Doctor are taxi drivers in Cuba (shocking!). People with two degrees from the UK are waiters and waitress (crazy!). As a young person myself, we are all told that if you want to make an income you need to get a job. But to get a decent paying job or a white collar job you'll need a degree. Once you have the degree you'll need work experience which you'll most likely gain through internships where there is no pay or very little and will mostly likely be utilized as a tool. For the same or similar roles/jobs for example Bartending, you can make around 25K (a year) USD or a little more or less in the US & Europe but in South East Asia, you'll make 5K USD a year! I'll be graduating in a month and can't wait to start washing dishes!

commentText: As a product development engineer in the US and a big believer in US manufacturing, I don't think this will bring manufacturing jobs back, at least not for a long while.   Any change in manufacturing locations will require capital investments, often significant ones. These involve significant loans, and even if interest rates are low now, a lot of these are variable rates, meaning they go up when prime lending rate does. When this happens, payments required will significantly increase, something that can ruin ROIs at best and send companies into instant default at worst.  My point is that for companies to make major changes to manufacturing, they need to spend a lot of capital, something they don't want to do with lots of economic uncertainty. Manufacturing that was planning to leave will probably be more likely to stay (as described with Nissan),  but not many will come back until there's stability in the forecast, something the current administration seems anathema to.

commentText: A trifecta of labor market readings just hit‚Äîand they all suggest a recession may already be underway:  ADP: 32,000 job losses in September  Indeed: Job openings index now back to pre-pandemic levels (-35% from peak)  BLS: Hiring rate has fallen to the lowest level since 2008‚Äì09  When three independent sources line up like this, it‚Äôs hard to ignore. Something is clearly breaking under the surface.  But here‚Äôs the twist: layoffs are still historically low, so the unemployment rate hasn‚Äôt moved much. At the same time, GDP growth and stock prices are still high. That‚Äôs why it doesn‚Äôt feel like a recession yet.  The impact I‚Äôm watching most closely is on housing. As job losses pick up and more households are forced to sell, housing demand will crack further. We‚Äôre already seeing a housing recession in half the U.S.‚Äîwith values dropping in places like Florida, Texas, and Arizona. The question is: how long before the pain spreads to other states?  üëâ Head to Reventure App  to track the data in your ZIP code. Pay close attention to inventory‚Äîif it‚Äôs spiking in your market, that‚Äôs a leading sign the recession is already underway, and cheaper home prices could be just around the corner. commentText: Interesting data on the job market as it shows Therapists leading with job growth. I'm a Licensed Psychotherapist in California and for the past 10 years I have tried to convince a few family/friends to get in the field. We enter the job market around $85k and at 5 years around $140k. I've been a therapist 16 years and can easily clear $200k+ all from the comfort of my home, thanks to covid forcing insurance companies to offer therapy via video. I encourage anyone who has a passion for helping others to consider the field. As long as there are people breathing, we will always be needed, and Ai cannot replace therapists or psychiatric evaluations. The ONLY downside, 9 years of schooling and clinical rotations to become an independent Licensed Psychotherapist, but it's definitely worth it!

commentText: I don't believe companies are being more productive due to AI. I believe they are still price gouging under the cover of general inflation. There are also few good places left to put all the cash that companies have accumulated while they were gouging during the pandemic so that money is going to the market. Consumers are spending more but buying less that's why it appears that consumers are ignoring inflation. They just have to keep paying more for the things they need to buy. I think if you look at it by category that discretionary spending is down for everyone but the very wealthy. The very wealthy are spending more because their wealth keeps going up. That spending at the very top is also making this look like average consumers are better off then they are.

commentText: The Stock market is driven by one thing: index funds / 401(k) plans.  It is the check box on your payroll.  Most people are doing the "smart thing" and checking "put my 401k into an index fund."  It is like a steamroller that does not care what the market does or what the fundamentals are doing.  It is DUMB MONEY.  I can only imagine what the pension managers are thinking as they have spent all that payroll money on an already inflated market and huge bubble.  At some point, when the number of people unemployed grows and the funding stream has less money, the redemptions will exceed the incoming funds, and we are all in for a trillion-dollar disaster.  Like the student loan fiasco brought to you by Congress, which removed the bankruptcy option, this mess is also of congressional making.

commentText: Real Estate is a slow moving market, even after the 2008 Recession, it wasn't until end of 2011 that Real Estate market bottomed. So, even if Recession starts tomorrow morning, based on historical data, it won't be until the end of 2028 that the Real Estate market will bottom. The Labor/Auto/Stock/Bonds/Derivatives/Commodities market go up and down really fast, but the Real Estate market is slow and sticky.  So, if you're someone who's looking to buy your first home, or maybe want to sell your current home and move somewhere else, but you don't like the current Real Estate market, then be ready to wait a couple more years for lower Home prices, and that too if there is a Recession within the next 3 to 6 months.

commentText: There is another phenomenon in the labor market that the payroll geeks point out that most people are missing in the official BLS numbers, including Bloomberg. There‚Äôs a growing skew between full-time and part-time jobs, with the former decreasing and the latter increasing, which is masking the job recession we‚Äôre already in. This is happening because when people lose their jobs now, many move into the gig economy (e.g., Uber, etc.) as part-timers and/or independent contractors and don‚Äôt file for unemployment because they can often earn more without it. It‚Äôs also causing a major distortion in the BLS business birth/death model employment growth estimates. The BDM looks at new businesses formed based on employer ID applications and assumes that each new business will hire a certain number of employees. But the problem is that most of the new businesses being formed are independent contractors going into the gig economy, who do not hire employees. As a result, unemployment figures reported by the BLS likely vastly underestimate both unemployment and underemployment, and the real unemployment rate is probably already deeply recessionary, in the 6‚Äì8% range. It really is different this time.

commentText: Pricing things in gold was one of the most important things I learned in university. It's the only constant you can use to get the true value and costs of things without getting bamboozled by manipulated statistics and the real effects of inflation. It was added into the curriculum by my finance professor; it wasn't included in the textbooks. He was retired from E.F. Hutton as a stockbroker/analyst and the banking industry. He taught the basics from the textbooks, but added in a lifetime of expertise in the industry, as well as personal observations on how to survive through the ups and downs of the economic cycles. He hammered home the importance of compound interest, long term effects of inflation, time in the markets, and how market psychology impacts the economy. Also, never fight the trends. Thank you Mr. Walters.

videoTitle: New data: 258k fewer jobs gained in May and June than first reported
videoDescription: The US job market slowed substantially in July and was much weaker than previously thought in previous months, suggesting ...
commentText: I was in the HVAC / sheet metal Union for over 20 years and the way these jobs work is there's a bid and the general contractor gets awarded the job. Let's say it's a big big job you know billion-dollar job. They bid. They bid these jobs by going off of the prices that they see present time and they even account for a small percentage for inflation but there's no way in hell they're going to account for 50% inflation due to a tariff. So if someone did a job for a billion dollars and they won the job and they're already broken ground and been on the job for a year, once Trump puts these tariffs on steel and copper and aluminum, it's basically going to shut that job down because the job was bid for a certain amount of money and now the tariffs are going to make that bid basically flush down the toilet and probably double the cost. So the jobs are going to end up shutting down because these jobs when they do get bid and a general contractor is awarded, that money that whoever the CEO or whoever is building the building or building the complex doesn't just have the cash in his pocket and it's painted out they usually get financed through these big hedge funds or special companies. So when they go get the financing they have to explain how much the buildings going to cost to build and how much it'll be worth once it's finished and then how much it'll be generating throughout the years and then how much it might be worth 10 years from now and blah blah blah they bring this all to the finances to show them that it's a good investment to loan them this money to build this building so what happens is, they agreed to invest a certain amount of money which whatever which is whatever the bid was and maybe a little extra for emergencies. So what happens with these tariffs is let's say the finances are financing a billion dollars and they've already given up 500 million and instead of the job needing another 500 million to finish now they need another 1.2 billion on top of the 500 million that's already spent and nine times out of 10 these finances aren't going to want to do it because they see that the return on investment is no longer there. And that's because of these tariffs. So you're going to see tons of jobs Across the Nation getting shut down which is going to shut down construction jobs and that's going to have a huge impact on how the jobs market and economy looks

I don't understand why school is so different now. My kids who went to school in the 2000's had a similar experience to mine. We also didn't have laptops and phones and neither did my kids. But what can you expect from a man who paid his sister to do his homework and paid someone else to take his college entrance exams etc. This is all common knowledge TRUMP himself has said these things in interviews from past years. What kind of future can we look forward to if we have an entire generation of poorly educated people? What does this mean future generations? This is becoming a truly terrifying time leading into a very bleak future.

commentText: There‚Äôs little reason to jump back into the job market these days‚Äîtaking a job rarely improves your long-term financial standing. For many long-term unemployed workers, getting laid off shortly after rehiring wipes out whatever stability they‚Äôd managed to rebuild, leaving them exactly where they started‚Äîas if they'd never taken the job at all.   So then... what‚Äôs the point? To endure toxic employers whose wages don‚Äôt cover basic living costs‚Äîat this stage, you‚Äôre basically paying the employer to work for them. That's madness‚Äîand yet it's probably many people's reality.   Delaying hiring like many of these companies are doing may protect employers‚Äô short-term profits, but over time it erodes workers' collective morale, shrinking the labor pool, as more people stop seeing traditional employment as a viable path forward.

commentText: Absolute truth about background checks. I work senior-level/team lead roles in IT, and for the past 15 years, I have had to pass drug screens, criminal background checks, and financial background checks for every single assignment. I've worked in a number of different industries including healthcare, education, fintech, energy, and banking. You can't get a job with highly-regulated industries unless you can pass all those checks. Doesn't matter your skill, degree, experience, or overall qualifications. I've had recruiters in fintech and banking tell me that for those roles, as long as I had no bankruptcies or judgements, we'd be OK to proceed with being hired.  If you let those areas slide, they can potentially haunt you for the rest of your life and kill any opportunity for a decent career and the benefits that come with it.

The job market is going to get even more competitive than it already is.

commentText: It‚Äôs sad that young adults entering college and even older adults returning to finish their degree or finally pursue higher education‚Äîare preparing for jobs that might not exist by the time they graduate. Roles like data entry, routine coding, legal research, and certain finance positions are already being automated. AI tools now handle these tasks faster, cheaper, and often more accurately than humans. Meanwhile, and while the next two have been the cycle of job market forever--it feels more rampant in this decade and probably forever but mass layoffs from all industries/verticals have seasoned professionals applying for entry-level jobs that are meant to be for these college grads, taking huge pay cuts just to survive, and employers are happy about that since they don't have to waste time training them and such. To top it off, companies keep outsourcing roles evern more so to cheaper labor overseas. It‚Äôs a rough reality for anyone entering the workforce right now.

Luckily it was sorted out but it cost us 6k of our savings that we only recently started putting money to again. commentText: It's not all entitled people with a BS college degree.  I worked in games for over 5 years before I was let go, before I could hit senior level. I was let go three years ago, and it's been a struggle getting back in. I had to go back to a retail job that pays minimum wage, and I'm lucky if I get 12 hours a week.   All the big gaming places are cutting back, and the little indie studios are wanting older, senior-level applicants who are willing to take less pay. I have applied to job postings that have been up for years now.  There are multiple factors. Companies that keep having open positions but are waiting for that unicorn candidate to come along.  Companies used to get a tax credit for hiring and training new, inexperienced candidates. But now that tax credit has expired, there is no incentive to hire them..  With interest rates so high, the tech companies do not want to take out alone to make anything and have to pay that back if the products fail. its all a mess

commentText: I normally like your podcasts, but this clip is horribly out of touch with the current job market. The official unemployment rate might be around 4%, but 20% of workers are underemployed in jobs that don't pay their basic living expenses, which causes them to go into debt or rely on government programs.  It's not all art majors that are having a hard time finding a job. Two of the majors with the highest unemployment rates among new college graduates are computer science and computer engineering, because the tech sector overhired a few years ago and is now laying off en masse. The new junior openings are being filled overseas or by desperste senior workers who have already been laid off.

commentText: As someone who works for Walmart and has been with the company for 15 years, I can guarantee that if someone appears to be overqualified with a degree, we probably don't want to hire them for entry level retail, because they probably don't want to be there, probably won't stay, and are just settling for something which they will do only until they can find a way to escape.  It just doesn't make sense to put someone through training just so they can quit two weeks later.  Also, employees who think that they are better than the position they're in tend to have a bad attitude and not really be committed to quality work.  If she would have just went to the interview and had an attitude of wanting the job as a longer term committment, they probably would have hired her.  There isn't a high bar at Walmart, and most stores are almost always hiring, as retail turnover is usually somewhere around 80-100%.

commentText: Veteran marketing exec here: that's not what's going on in marketing. The industry is oversaturated with mediocre people who think having a TikTok account = marketing. Content creators are the ones getting replaced by AI. People who want a job in this industry need to sharpen their tech and strategy skills. Marketing doesn't equal social media. That's a teeny tiny slice of the pie. It's also simply a single tactic in one channel among many. The real money is knowing how to create strategies that move the needle ($$$) and how to use tech to enhance your results. You know, the real work behind the scenes.   What you're talking about paying content creators is promotion. Again, just a small slice of what "marketing" is in the real world. The money in marketing typically isn't in the "fun, sexy" promo nonsense people think of when they think of marketing. Companies still have heads of marketing that make those decisions. They're just shifting budgeted media dollars from traditional buys to content creators.

commentText: If you actually want to land a job‚Äîand help shift the market while you're at it‚Äîstop applying to everything. If enough people cut their job applications by 75%, employers will start to feel the drop in demand. Suddenly, their "we‚Äôll get back to you" mindset flips to "why isn‚Äôt anyone applying?"  Of the 25% of roles you do go after, be selective‚Äîlike you're the one with options. Because you are. For half, list your actual target salary. For the other half, triple it. Not because you're greedy‚Äîbut because you're helping set a new norm. When companies see fewer applicants and higher wage expectations, they‚Äôre forced to act faster and start valuing talent more realistically.  And here‚Äôs the kicker: this shift is only fair. With AI, the average worker now produces 2‚Äì3x more than before. So why should you settle for less?  You can all race to the bottom‚Äîor you can move in sync and make the market adjust to you. The power‚Äôs not in one application. It‚Äôs in all of ours, together.

commentText: Why do these videos continue to overlook older American workers, as if their struggles don‚Äôt matter? Just because they aren‚Äôt actively complaining on TikTok (they don't have the time) doesn‚Äôt mean they aren‚Äôt suffering - they are!, and they have been for decades. This crisis is not new.  For example, older American technology workers - forced into chronic unemployment or underemployment due to cheap labor and outsourcing since the early 90s - are now reaching retirement age with insufficient savings and inadequate Social Security contributions (due to being chronically locked out, not financial irresponsibility). The financial devastation they‚Äôve faced over decades has left them without a path to retirement, facing the grim reality of total financial insecurity. They're not young; and they do not have the luxury of time (time horizon) to wait for any "market correction." Their livelihoods were ripped away.  These are people who adapted, who educated and even re-educated themselves as technology endlessly evolved - who paid their debts and fulfilled their obligations - only to find themselves abandoned in old age. Their plight should not be ignored. They deserve advocacy, and even be the centerpiece of your videos because theirs is a dire situation now.

commentText: Yeah Republic services the one that's out of Hudson Florida there, they are a garbage collection business. They've had to close up because they've lost major county accounts I guess, at least here in Hernando county. The counties were drawing up contracts for new waste disposal and Republic came up a little bit more money than the other service that put their bid in, so that's probably why they've had to close that down.  The economy here is interesting to say the least. If you're coming from another state and you're used to getting paid more money, you will get paid a lot less here but you'll be paying more for housing and rent. The governor just announced today that they are going to put a referendum on November 2026 ballot. He's trying to do away with property taxes. Florida would be the first state to not have any property tax. In a good economy, this would probably would work for us, but it's a little early to say that they will be able to get money from other places to cover services.  I think if they can make it work it will cause a major housing boom down here. There are houses being built and apartment buildings being built right and left, but nobody's moving into them yet. Our housing market is teetering as homeowners insurance is so incredibly expensive in some areas. And for everyone that's noticed that our hurricane season has been slow, (we don't use the Q word) that is absolutely not normal! Lucky, but not normal! So please don't think that you can come to Florida and escape hurricanes, because it's kind of our thing and it's what we do.üòä Good luck out there.
